definition.meaning: Any sleight of hand that can be done with cards (anything from magic tricks to cardistry)

introduction.goal: To encourage others to learn and practice card tricks

tutorial.name: 21 Cards
tutorial.description: The spectator chooses one of 21 standard, randomly picked, shuffled cards, they are then dealt out face up in 3 columns of 7 cards, the spectator points to the column with his card for the magician, the cards get picked up and the process is repeated 2 more times. At the end the magician reveals the card selected by the spectator.
It actually doesn't involve any sleight of hand, it's based on math.

step.instructions: Prepare a pile of 21 standard playing cards
Let the spectator choose one of 21 cards, tell them to carefully memorize it
Shuffle the cards and lay them out in 3 columns of 7 cards (row by row)
Ask the spectator to point to the column where his card is
Pick up the cards, put the pile with the spectator's card in the middle, between the other 2 packets
Repeat the last 3 steps 2 more times
The spectator's card will now be in the 11th position from the top

gif.caption: An animation to help visualize how the trick works

tutorial.name: Reversed Card
tutorial.description: The spectator picks a random card from a standard deck of cards, memorizes it, then puts it back. The magician snaps his fingers and spreads out the cards, the card picked by the spectator is the only one facing the other way, it has been "magically" reversed.
It all bases off of a simple idea and clever misdirection.

step.instructions: Take the card at the bottom of the deck and flip it.
step.sidenote: This is usually done before approaching the spectator, but if you're clever with your misdirection you can do it directly in front of them.

step.instructions: Let the spectator choose their card, be careful not to show the last one.

While the spectator is trying to memorize their card sneakily flip the deck. Thanks to the card we flipped before it won't look any different, but in actuality all of the cards except the top one will now be face up.
Take the card from the spectator and put it back somewhere in the middle of the deck, be careful not to let the cards spread out.

You have to bring the attention of the spectator somewhere else (chatting them up, recounting what happend so far in the trick, talking in some shape or form usually does the trick) and sneakily flip the deck once again. If you can manage it you should also flip the bottom card once again to return to it to it's normal orientation.
step.sidenote: For a beginner this might be the hardest part

step.instructions: Build some tension: snap your fingers, wave your hand, at this point as long as you flipped the bottom card you can even give the deck back to the spectator.
At long last spread the cards out and reveal that one card has been "magically" fliped and that it is precisely the spectator's card.

recommendations.recommendation: Simply pick up any deck of cards and start practicing, that's the beauty of it, if you have a deck of cards (even simple, paper ones) in your household you can see if it's something you like even right now.

Once you get a feel for things, and have invested some time into it and concluded that it's something you enjoy, consider investing into a Bicycle Deck, they are great no matter the level of mastery of card tricks. You can find them virtually in any shop that sells things like these, but here is an example link https://www.empik.com/bicycle-standard-back-red-karty-klasyczne-rewers-czerwony-u-s-playing-card-company,p1374794845,zabawki-p
Never do the same trick twice for the same person. (Rules exist to be broken of course, but do it only if you're really sure you can get away with it, it'll save you a lot of headaches).
